flds.name: Hide others on the back side

note_models.name: Cloze (Hide all)-8ef4c

tmpls.afmt:
<script>
/* --- DO NOT DELETE OR EDIT THIS SCRIPT --- */
setTimeout(function() {
    var clozeBoxes = document.querySelector(".cloze cloze2_w");
    var elements = document.querySelectorAll("cloze2." + clozeBoxes.className);
    for(var i = 0 ; i < elements.length ; i++) {
        elements[i].style.display="inline";
    }
}, 0);
/* --- DO NOT DELETE OR EDIT THIS SCRIPT --- */
</script>


<script>
/* --- DO NOT DELETE OR EDIT THIS SCRIPT --- */
setTimeout(function() {
    var clozeBoxes = document.querySelector(".cloze cloze2_w");
    var elements = document.querySelectorAll("cloze2." + clozeBoxes.className);
    for(var i = 0 ; i < elements.length ; i++) {
        elements[i].classList.add("cloze");
        elements[i].style.display="inline";
    }
}, 0);
/* --- DO NOT DELETE OR EDIT THIS SCRIPT --- */
</script>



{{cloze:Text}}
{{#Extra}}
<hr>
{{Extra}}
{{/Extra}}

{{#Hide others on the back side}}
<style>
cloze2 {
    display: none;
}

cloze2_w {
    display: inline-block;
    width: 5em;
    height: 1em;
    background-color: #ffeba2;
}

.cloze cloze2 {
    display: inline;
}

.cloze cloze2_w {
    display: none;
}

cloze2.reveal-cloze2 {
    display: inline;
}

cloze2_w.reveal-cloze2 {
    display: none;
}

.cloze2-toggle {
    -webkit-appearance: none;
    display: block;
    font-size: 1.3em;
    height: 2em;
    background-color: #ffffff;
    width: 100%;
    margin-top: 20px;
}

.cloze2-toggle:active {
    background-color: #ffffaa;
}
</style>

<script>
function toggle() {
var elements = document.querySelectorAll('cloze2, cloze2_w');
    for(var i = 0 ; i < elements.length ; i++) {
        elements[i].classList.toggle('reveal-cloze2');
    }
}
</script>



<button class='cloze2-toggle' onclick='toggle()'>Toogle mask</button>
{{/Hide others on the back side}}

<script>
var createCookie = function(name, value, days) {
    var expires;
    if (days) {
        var date = new Date();
        date.setTime(date.getTime() + (days * 24 * 60 * 60 * 1000));
        expires = "; expires=" + date.toGMTString();
    }
    else {
        expires = "";
    }
    document.cookie = name + "=" + value + expires + "; path=/";
}
function getCookie(c_name) {
    if (document.cookie.length > 0) {
        c_start = document.cookie.indexOf(c_name + "=");
        if (c_start != -1) {
            c_start = c_start + c_name.length + 1;
            c_end = document.cookie.indexOf(";", c_start);
            if (c_end == -1) {
                c_end = document.cookie.length;
            }
            return unescape(document.cookie.substring(c_start, c_end));
        }
    }
    return "";
}
function getRandomElms(){
    var ul = document.querySelectorAll('ul.shuffle');
    return ul
}
function getRandArr(elm, array){
    for (var i = elm.children.length; i >= 0; i--) {
        rand = Math.random() * i | 0;
        array.push(rand)
    }
}
function shuffleWithArr(elm, array){
    elm.style.backgroundColor = "inherit"
    for (var i = elm.children.length; i >= 0; i--) {
        elm.appendChild(elm.children[array[i]]);
    }
}
function run() {
    var elms = getRandomElms()
    var isFront = document.getElementById("front");
    for (var i = 0; i < elms.length; i++) {
        var idxArr = [];
        elm = elms[i]
        if (isFront) {
            getRandArr(elm, idxArr);
            // convert idxArr array to a JSON string to be stored
            var json_str = JSON.stringify(idxArr);
            // persist the idxArr order and correct answers
            createCookie('idxArr' + i, json_str);
            var stored_data = idxArr
        } else {
            // get the idxArr order
            var json_data = getCookie('idxArr' + i);
            // get the array back from storage
            var stored_data = JSON.parse(json_data);
        }
        shuffleWithArr(elm, stored_data)
    }
}
run();
</script>

note_models.name: Cloze-a78cb
Cloze

fields: Surface of cell defined by: {{c1::<cloze2_w class='cz-1'></cloze2_w><cloze2 class='cz-1'>Membrane</cloze2>}}

Cell membrane permeability

Substance: degree of permeability
Nucleic acids: {{c1::Impermeable}}
Proteins: {{c2::Impermeable}}
Ions: {{c3::Selectively permeable}}
Metabolites: {{c4::Selectively permeable}}

Cell membrane

More than passive barrier
-> able to move molecules against {{c2::concentration gradient}} ("{{c1::active transport}}", which would {{c3:: ::yes/no}} require energy)

Cell membrane

Constituents
{{c1::lipids}} -> mostly {{c1::phospholipids}}
{{c2::Proteins}}

Cell membrane

Constituents

Phospholipid
Properties
Head: {{c1::charged/polar::property}} -> hydroph{{c1::ilic}}
Fatty acid tail: {{c2::non polar}} -> {{c2::hydrophobic}}

Molecule with both polar and non polar portion: "{{c3::amphipathic}}"

Cell membrane

Phospholipid bilayer
Can be dissolved by {{c1::detergents}} (which are also {{c2::amphipathic}})

Cell membrane

Phospholipid bilayer

dynamics in different temperature
^ temperature - {{c1::faster}} lateral diffusion: "{{c3::Sol}} state"
v temperature - {{c2::slower}} lateral diffusion: "{{c4::Gel}} state"

Cell membrane

Phospholipid bilayer

dynamics in different temperature
^ temperature - {{c1::faster}} lateral diffusion: "{{c3::Sol}} state"
v temperature - {{c2::slower}} lateral diffusion: "{{c4::Gel}} state"

Temp between the two states: {{c5::!Transition Temperature}}
Phospholipid witn long, saturated FA chain: {{c7::^::^/v}} {{c5::!Transition temperature}}

Cell membrane

Phospholipid 

Most common type: {{c1::glyceral}} based phospholipid
e.g. 
Phosphatidylinositol
Phosphatidylserine
Phosphatidylcholine

Cell membrane

Phospholipid 

Less common type: {{c1::sphingosine}} based phospholipid
e.g. 
Sphingolipids
Glycosphingolipids
Gangliosides

Cell membrane

Phospholipid 

Types
Phosphatidylinositol - {{c1::Glycerol}}-based
Phosphatidylserine - {{c2::Glycerol}}-based
Phosphatidylcholine - {{c3::Glycerol}}-based
Sphingomyelin - {{c4::Sphongosine}}-based
Galactocerebroside - {{c5::Sphingosine}}-based

Cell membrane

Cholesterol

rigid {{c1::stroid}} ring bind to FA {{c2::side chains}}
-> {{c4::reduce::increase/reduce}} membrane fluidity

Cell membrane

Constituent movements

Horizontal movementFlipping
Phospholipids{{c1::Yes}}{{c3::Rarely}}
Cholesterol{{c2::Yes}}{{c4::Easily}}

Cell membrane

Pospholipid bilayer

{{c1::Im::yes/no}}permeable to {{c2::charged}} molecules -> suited to separate two {{c3::aqueous compartments}}

Cell membrane

Pospholipid bilayer
Permeability to

Na+ - {{c1::Impermeable}}
K+ - {{c2::Impermeable}}
Cl- - {{c3::Impermeable}}
Ca++ - {{c4::Impermeable}}
Proteins - {{c5::Impermeable}}
Nucleic acids- {{c6::Impermeable}}
sugars - {{c7::Impermeable}}
Nucleotides - {{c8::Impermeable}}
O2 -{{c9::Permeable}}
CO2 - {{c10::Permeable}}
NH3 - {{c11::Permeable}}
Water - {{c12::Permeable}}

Cell membrane

Pospholipid bilayer
Constituents in different leaflets:

Phosphatidylethanolamine - {{c1::cytoplasm}} side
Phosphatidylserine - {{c2::cytoplasm}} side
Phosphatidylcholine - {{c3::extracellular}} side

{{c3::Integral proteins}}

For physical contact 
with surrounding extracellular matrix: {{c1::Cell-matrix adhesion molecules}}
Cellular neighbors: {{c2::Cell-cell adhesion molecules}}

Cell Memebrane

{{c1::Integrins}}:

{{c2::Cell-matrix}} adhesion molecule
Linking cells to {{c2::extra::extra/intra}}cellular components e.g.
{{c3::fibronectin}}
{{c4::laminin}}

Extracellular signal tansduced to {{c5::cytoplasmic tail}} linked to signaling or structural molecules

Cell Memebrane

{{c1::Cell-cell}} adhesion molecules

e.g.
{{c2::Ca-dependent adhesion molecules}} ({{c3::Cadherin}})
{{c4::Ca-independent neural cell adhesion molecule}} ({{c5::N-CAM}})

Cell Memebrane

{{c1::Cell-cell}} adhesion molecules

Calcium dependency:
Cadherin - Ca-{{c2::dependent::dependent/independent}}
N-CAM - Ca-{{c3::independent::dependent/independent}}

Transmembrane proteins:

{{c1::Pores}} and {{c1::Channels}}:
Permit {{c5::passive diffusion}} of water, specific ions, and proteins
{{c3::Carriers}}:
Faciliatate transport of specific molecule
{{c4::Pumps}}:
Powered (via {{c6::hydrolysis of ATP}}) pumps to transport substances {{c7::against chemical gradients}}.

Transmembrane proteins:

Transmembrane proteins
# of gates
{{c1::Pore}}: none
{{c2::Channel}}: 1
{{c3::Carrier}}: 2

Transmembrane proteins:

Transmembrane proteins
{{c1::Pore}}:
{{c2::Channel}}
{{c3::Carrier}}
{{c4::Pump}}
{{c1::Peripheral}} proteins adhere tightly to the cytoplasmic or extracellular surfaces of the plasma membrane by {{c2::non-covalent bonds}}.
{{c1::Peripheral}} proteins adhere tightly to the cytoplasmic or extracellular surfaces of the plasma membrane by {{c2::non-covalent bonds}}.
{{c1::Integral}} proteins are embedded within the membrane or attached by {{c2::covalent bonds.}}
T/F Integral proteins only span the membrane one time.
False- Integral proteins can span the membrane one or more times.
T/F Some integral proteins are embedded without crossing the membrane.
True
T/F Transmembrane proteins are in a fixed position within the membrane.
False - in the absence of protein-protein attachments, transmembrane proteins are free to diffuse over the entire surface of the membrane.
Some {{c1::integral proteins}} are attached by covalent bonds to lipids within the membrane. An exampe of a lipid is {{c1::glycosylphosphatidylinositol(GPI) }}
Most membrane spanning segments are composed of {{c1::alpha helices}} containing mainly {{c1::nonpolar}} amino acids along with some {{c1::polar uncharged}} amino acids.
T/F Transmembrane proteins diffuse within the plane of the phospholipid membrane slower than lipids.
True- because proteins are much larger.
T/F Like Phospholipids, proteins can diffuse only in the plane of the bilayer and not across.
True
Integrap proteins can serve as: {{c1::receptors}}, {{c1::adhesion molecules}}, {{c1::transporters}}, {{c1::enzymes}}, and {{c1::signal transduction components}}.

Essentially all communication functions served through the plasma membrane occur through membrane {{c1::proteins.}} The exception is {{c1::lipid solluble}} signalling molecules such as {{c1::steroid hormones}}.
{{c1::Integral proteins}} serve as recepetors that transmit signals between the cell and {{c2::its environment. }}

Integral proteins are ideally suited to act as receptors because they form a {{c1::continuous}} link between the {{c1::intracellular}} and {{c1::extracellular}} compartments of the cell that is seprated by the membrane.
{{c1::Hormones}} binding to receptors on the outsides of the cell often causes a {{c2::conformational change}} that is transmitted through the membrane spanning region to the interior of the cell.
What two things may occur intracellularly after a hormone has bound to a integral protein that is acting as a receptor?

1. The intracellular region of the integral protein may become active if it has enzymatic capabilities 
2. The integral protein acts with cytoplasmic proteins that are involved in the generation of second messangers.
